docs.snippet: To the Editor:   In a recent news article about book publishing (''Agent Says Writers Are Cheated,'' Feb. 4), you gave the views of the literary agent Richard Curtis that ''publishers have always cheated authors'' and that ''some publishers are st...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In a recent news article about book publishing (''Agent Says Writers Are Cheated,'' Feb. 4), you gave the views of the literary agent Richard Curtis that ''publishers have always cheated authors'' and that ''some publishers are still cheating authors.'' That authors believe publishers to be thieves is hardly news. Oscar Wilde claimed that ''Barabbas was a publisher.'' I can't attest to whether publishers have always cheated authors because I haven't been around that long, but I can say from personal and all-too-recent experience that authors cheat publishers: By taking money in advance and never delivering a single page of their manuscript; by running up charges which they never repay, although these are by contract clear debts; by failing to return money on contracts where the obligation for such return is clearly stated and previously agreed to; by falsifying the sales records of their previous books when trying to interest a new and different publisher in their next work; by showing their next work to a different publisher (and soliciting offers from same) when by agreement they are obliged show it to their present publisher first; by submitting phony expense accounts when on promotional tours.

headline.main: OF AUTHORS, PUBLISHERS AND GLASS HOUSES

docs.snippet: Oscar Gamble looks at the designated-hitter spot in the Yankee lineup and sees Don Baylor. He looks at right field and sees Steve Kemp. He looks at left field and sees Dave Winfield. What Oscar Gamble doesn't see when he looks at the Yankees' line...
docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar Gamble looks at the designated-hitter spot in the Yankee lineup and sees Don Baylor. He looks at right field and sees Steve Kemp. He looks at left field and sees Dave Winfield. What Oscar Gamble doesn't see when he looks at the Yankees' lineup is a spot for Oscar Gamble. ''Nobody has said anything to me,'' Gamble said today, ''but if I'm not going to play against right-handers, I want to be traded. It's my option year, so I want to go somewhere where I can get some at-bats. I don't want to wait to find out. They can tell me now.''

byline.original: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: BLANK WALLS   When the author and film maker William H. Whyte looks at Atlanta, Denver, San Francisco, Baltimore, New York and other American cities he sees a ''blank wall.''   A blank wall, to Mr. Whyte, is the huge, empty space one finds on many...
docs.lead_paragraph: BLANK WALLS When the author and film maker William H. Whyte looks at Atlanta, Denver, San Francisco, Baltimore, New York and other American cities he sees a ''blank wall.'' A blank wall, to Mr. Whyte, is the huge, empty space one finds on many government buildings, telephone-company headquarters and convention centers. These walls, Mr. Whyte says, ''proclaim the power of the institution, and the inconsequence of the individual.'' An exhibit of his color photographs of blank walls from around the United States, with written commentary, is currently on display at the Municipal Arts Society's Urban Center. In the exhibit, Mr. Whyte hopes to show that a trend toward building blank walls is spreading in the downtown areas of major American cities.

docs.snippet: Pope John Paul II arrives here Wednesday to start an eight-day trip through Central America, a region as bitterly divided over religion as it is over politics.   In several of the eight countries on his itinerary, religious conflicts within the Ro...
docs.lead_paragraph: Pope John Paul II arrives here Wednesday to start an eight-day trip through Central America, a region as bitterly divided over religion as it is over politics. In several of the eight countries on his itinerary, religious conflicts within the Roman Catholic Church and between Catholics and Protestant denominations have even become part of often-violent political struggles. As a result, even though the Pope has emphasized ''the eminently religious'' character of his trip to the convulsed region, his visit will unavoidably have an enormous political impact on Central America. Advantages for Politicians ''People in the region are very devout,'' one Guatemalan priest said, noting that huge crowds are expected to accompany the Pope at every stage, ''so politicians always want religion on their side. That's why everyone is trying to get something out of the Pope's visit.''

headline.main: POLITICS AND RELIGION DIVIDED AND ENTWINED ON POPE'S ROUTE

byline.original: By ALAN RIDING, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Negotiators for the National Basketball Association and the union representing its players met yesterday for the first time since the setting of an April 2 strike deadline, but the talks broke off after 24 fruitless minutes, and no further session...
docs.lead_paragraph: Negotiators for the National Basketball Association and the union representing its players met yesterday for the first time since the setting of an April 2 strike deadline, but the talks broke off after 24 fruitless minutes, and no further session was scheduled. ''There is no purpose served, under the circumstances, to continue meeting,'' Commissioner Larry O'Brien said at a news conference afterward. ''The players are free at any time to respond to the problems of this league. They have been invited to contact us if they have thoughts or recommendations in this area.''

docs.snippet: On the eve of his departure on an eight-nation tour of Central America and Haiti, Pope John Paul II named a new Archbishop of San Salvador today to fill the post left vacant since the assassination in 1980 of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero.   Mon...
docs.lead_paragraph: On the eve of his departure on an eight-nation tour of Central America and Haiti, Pope John Paul II named a new Archbishop of San Salvador today to fill the post left vacant since the assassination in 1980 of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero. Monsignor Romero was shot dead as he celebrated mass on March 24, 1980. His murderers have not been identified, but right-wing terrorists are suspected.

byline.original: By HENRY KAMM, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Best-selling styles on Seventh Avenue provide a good idea of how women will dress this spring and summer. These are the clothes ordered heavily by stores throughout the country. The emphasis they are placing on some specific types will also have a...
docs.lead_paragraph: Best-selling styles on Seventh Avenue provide a good idea of how women will dress this spring and summer. These are the clothes ordered heavily by stores throughout the country. The emphasis they are placing on some specific types will also have an influence on the clothes designers will present for next fall and winter. Design rooms have already switched from the production of warm-weather fashions to fashions for winter, the strongest selling season. Variations on the coat dress are likely to turn up with increasing frequency, judging from the popularity of this style for spring and summer.

docs.snippet: EN AVANT   The Performing Garage, in its interestingly alterable quarters at 33 Wooster Street in SoHo, north of Canal Street (966-3651), is the quintessence of avant-garde in New York. From its very start during the tumultuous 1960's, the dramati...
docs.lead_paragraph: EN AVANT The Performing Garage, in its interestingly alterable quarters at 33 Wooster Street in SoHo, north of Canal Street (966-3651), is the quintessence of avant-garde in New York. From its very start during the tumultuous 1960's, the dramatics at the Garage have taken turns for the unexpected. Tonight, the Garage opens its doors, through mid-June, for outside groups to display their experimental approaches. Two of the eight groups on the schedule will perform dance. The six other events will involve performance-art theater, four of them presented by groups from the San Francisco area; the two other events are by New York women artists.

docs.snippet: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip were treated to a slice of the American dream today when they traveled to Rancho Mirage, 15 miles southeast of Palm Springs, to lunch at one of the country's most luxurious estates.   The 205-acre desert oasis ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip were treated to a slice of the American dream today when they traveled to Rancho Mirage, 15 miles southeast of Palm Springs, to lunch at one of the country's most luxurious estates. The 205-acre desert oasis is owned by Walter H. Annenberg, the publishing magnate who served as Ambassador to Britain in the Nixon Administration, and his wife, Leonore, who served as chief of protocol in the first 11 months of the Reagan Administration. Tonight a setting that was a Hollywood version of a Hollywood party awaited the royal couple at the studios of 20th Century-Fox here. Others expected to attend included 500 movie stars, politicians, business leaders and social figures, the winners in a battle for invitations that had been going on for weeks. The 190- by 100-foot Stage 9, where the television series ''M*A*S*H'' was filmed, was transformed, with the aid of movie backgrounds and props, into a California garden, set with peach moire-covered tables and ready for a dinner of papaya with bay shrimp, chicken pot pie and snowballs of vanilla ice cream rolled in toasted coconut and topped with hot chocolate sauce.

headline.main: ESTATE IS ROYAL SETTING FOR ROYAL VISIT

byline.original: By ENID NEMY, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: It was once called ''a sin center'' where nightclubs doubled as brothels and quickie divorces were a major industry. Now the Mexican border town of Juarez is trying to clean up its streets and its image.   ''Juarez has very complex problems,'' May...
docs.lead_paragraph: It was once called ''a sin center'' where nightclubs doubled as brothels and quickie divorces were a major industry. Now the Mexican border town of Juarez is trying to clean up its streets and its image. ''Juarez has very complex problems,'' Mayor Jose Reyes Estrada says. ''We must work now for solutions.'' With three devaluations of the Mexican peso last year, a local unemployment rate of about 35 percent and American tourists' fears of driving into Mexico because of reports of unrest and maltreatment of tourists, the city of 900,000 across the Rio Grande from El Paso, Tex., may have a hard time.

headline.main: JUAREZ WORKS HARD TO CLEAN UP STREETS AND IMAGE
